body:
John Eynon

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
Jump to navigation Jump to search

Blessed John Eynon
Martyr
Died 15 November 1539
Reading Abbey, Berkshire, England
Venerated in Catholic Church
Beatified 13 May 1895, Rome by Pope Leo XIII

The Blessed John Eynon O.S.B. (?–1539) was a member of the Order of Saint Benedict who acted as the pastor of the parish of St Giles in Reading , England. Copies Robert Aske 's proclamation setting forth the reasons behind the Pilgrimage of Grace had circulated at Reading. Eynon was one of those who had made a copy. [1]

At the dissolution of the monasteries under King Henry VIII , Eynon refused to surrender the parish to the King's authorities and was accused of high treason . He was executed on 15 November 1539 at the gateway to Reading Abbey , along with Hugh Faringdon and John Rugg . All three men were declared to be martyrs and beatified by Pope Leo XIII in 1895. [2] [3]

John Eynon is commemorated by a carved wooden plaque in St Giles' Church , now a Church of England parish church, and by a stained glass window in St James' Church , the Roman Catholic parish church that occupies part of the footprint of the now ruined Reading Abbey. He is also depicted on The Martyrdom of Hugh Faringdon, last Abbot of Reading , painted by Harry Morley in 1917, and now in the collection of the Museum of Reading . [4] [5] [6]

References [ edit ]

  1. ^ Camm OSB, Bede. "The Blessed Hugh Faringdon", Lives of the English Martyrs , Longmans, Green and Co., 1914, p. 369 This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the public domain .
  2. ^ "Bl. John Eynon" . catholic.org . Retrieved 24 October 2017 .
  3. ^ "Blessed John Eynon" . CatholicSaints.Info . 13 November 2015 . Retrieved 24 October 2017 .
  4. ^ "History of S Giles-in-Reading" . St Giles' Church . Retrieved 25 October 2017 .
  5. ^ "The North Aisle" . Roman Catholic Parish of St James and St William of York Reading . Retrieved 25 October 2017 .
  6. ^ "The Martyrdom of Hugh Faringdon, last Abbot of Reading" . Museum of Reading. Archived from the original on 25 October 2017 . Retrieved 25 October 2017 .
